No significant differences were observed in walking speed or cadence between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with plantar fasciitis (n=49, split into LLLT group n=27 and control group n=22).
effective_dosage: Gallium-aluminum-arsenide laser with 850-nm wavelength, administered three times a week for ten sessions.
study_duration: 3 months (with assessments at baseline, 3 weeks, and 3 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) using GaAlAs laser and lidocaine 2% infiltration in patients with orofacial pain and fibromyalgia.
results_summary: Both LLLT and lidocaine significantly reduced pain (p=0.0001) with no statistical difference between treatments (p=0.46). Tender points decreased in most masticatory muscles, and patients perceived both treatments as effective.
population_specificity: Adults with orofacial pain and fibromyalgia (N=66).
effective_dosage: LLLT (780nm) twice a week for six weeks; lidocaine 2% once a week for four weeks.
study_duration: Six weeks for LLLT, four weeks for lidocaine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), also known as photobiomodulation (PBM) therapy, in managing breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
results_summary: The study found strong evidence that LLLT (PBM) was more effective than sham treatment for reducing limb circumference/volume in the short term, moderate evidence for short-term pain relief, and limited evidence for decreasing limb swelling compared to no treatment.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
effective_dosage: Not specified (reporting of treatment parameters was poor).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze non-specific effects (placebo, spontaneous remission, regression to the mean) of LLLT in women with myofascial pain (TMD) and differentiate responders from non-responders based on anxiety, cortisol, oral contraceptive use, and premenstrual period.
results_summary: The study compared LLLT, placebo, and no-treatment groups but did not explicitly report efficacy outcomes in the abstract. It focused on differentiating responders and non-responders based on psychological and physiological factors.
population_specificity: 64 women diagnosed with myofascial pain (TMD).
effective_dosage: 780 nm, masseter and temporal = 5 J/cm² (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in improving post-burn scar tissue in children compared to topical treatment alone.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in scar tissue treated with LLLT and topical therapy compared to topical treatment alone, as measured by the Vancouver Scar Scale and ultrasonography. No significant difference in blood perfusion was observed, and no adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 15 children aged 2-10 years with burn scars.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate effect of LLLT on muscle fiber conduction velocity (MFCV) and electromyographic activity (EMG) of the upper trapezius muscle in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study compared active LLLT (820 nm, 30 mW, 18 J total energy) with placebo LLLT, measuring sEMG signals during shoulder elevation contractions. Results indicated changes in MFCV and sEMG amplitude post-intervention, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 20 healthy subjects
effective_dosage: 820 nm wavelength, 30 mW, total energy 18 J (single session)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the gene expression of inflammatory/reparative factors (IL6, TNF, VEGF, TGF) involved in tissue healing under the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in pressure ulcers.
results_summary: The study analyzed lesion area and gene expression changes before and after LLLT, suggesting potential effects on tissue healing, though specific quantitative results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Eight individuals (mean age 62) with sacroiliac and calcaneous pressure ulcers (degree III and IV per NPUAP).
effective_dosage: InGaAIP laser, 100 mW, 660 nm, energy density 2 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal timing (before, after, or both) of PBMT application during aerobic training and its effects on endurance and body composition.
results_summary: PBMT applied both before and after aerobic exercise significantly improved time until exhaustion, oxygen uptake, and body fat reduction compared to placebo, with benefits observed as early as 4 weeks and sustained through 12 weeks.
population_specificity: 77 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 30 J per site (17 sites per lower limb, using a cluster of 12 diodes: 4 × 905 nm super-pulsed laser diodes, 4 × 875 nm infrared LEDs, and 4 × 640 nm red LEDs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of photobiomodulation (PBM) for treating traumatic brain injury (TBI) by examining its mechanisms of action and clinical effects.
results_summary: PBM showed positive effects in animal models and human studies, including improved neurological function, reduced inflammation, enhanced memory, mood, and cognitive function, and modulation of brain networks affected by TBI. Clinical studies in chronic TBI patients reported improvements in executive function, working memory, and sleep.
population_specificity: Small animal models, healthy human volunteers (students and elderly women), and patients with chronic TBI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of photodynamic therapy (PDT) and low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis in pediatric patients.
results_summary: Both PDT and LLLT showed significant pain reduction and similar clinical cure rates for oral lesions, with no statistical difference between the two treatments. The number needed to treat (NNT) was 4.75, indicating moderate clinical benefit.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 10 months to 18 years with chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis.
effective_dosage: LLLT was administered at 1J energy per point (λ660 nm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize clinical evidence on the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in preventing and treating chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis in pediatric and young patients.
results_summary: Prophylactic LLLT significantly reduced the occurrence and severity of oral mucositis, while therapeutic LLLT reduced severity and oral pain compared to routine care. The meta-analysis included 8 clinical trials with 373 pediatric patients, showing statistically significant benefits.
population_specificity: Pediatric and young patients receiving chemotherapy for cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the in vitro effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and Low Intensity Pulsed Ultrasound (LIPUS) on bony cells and related stem cells.
results_summary: The study found that both LLLT and LIPUS have a biostimulatory effect on osteoblasts, osteocytes, and stem cells, enhancing proliferation and differentiation, which may be useful for bone regeneration therapy. LLLT, in particular, significantly increased the initial number of stem cells before differentiation, benefiting tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.
population_specificity: In vitro studies on bony cells, stem cells, and related cell lines (e.g., human osteosarcoma cell line MG63).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of three different LLLT doses on VO₂ and exercise tolerance in competitive cyclists.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT increased exercise tolerance in male competitive cyclists, with effects observed across three different doses (3, 6, and 9 J/diode). The abstract suggests potential benefits for sports performance but does not detail VO₂ outcomes.
population_specificity: Male competitive cyclists

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating xerostomia in patients with primary Sjögren's syndrome.
results_summary: The study compared LLLT to placebo in 66 patients, with the laser group receiving 12 treatment sessions over 6 weeks. Results suggested potential efficacy, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome data.
population_specificity: Patients with dry mouth symptoms associated with primary Sjögren's syndrome receiving care at a university hospital.
effective_dosage: 808 nm wavelength, 100-mW output power, energy density of 4.0 J/cm², administered twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) at different doses on neuromuscular economy during submaximal running tests.
results_summary: The study compared PBMT at doses of 15, 30, and 60 J per site (14 sites per lower limb) against control and placebo conditions during submaximal running at 8 and 9 km/h, but the abstract does not specify the outcomes.
population_specificity: Eighteen male recreational runners.
effective_dosage: 15, 30, and 60 J per site (14 sites per lower limb).

study_goal: To investigate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) applied to the PC6 acupuncture point reduces gag reflex, regulates pulse rates and oxygen saturation, and lowers anxiety levels.
results_summary: LLLT on the PC6 point significantly reduced gag reflex, regulated pulse rates and oxygen saturation to normal levels, and lowered anxiety as measured by the modified anxiety rating scale.
population_specificity: 40 patients aged 4-14 years with hyperactive gag reflex.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in improving dental implant stability.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in implant stability between the LLLT and control groups over time, though the laser group showed a slower reduction in stability initially and a slight increase from the 6th to 12th week. LLLT did not significantly affect dental implant stability.
population_specificity: 19 patients with 80 dental implants.
effective_dosage: Seven sessions of LLLT (940 nm diode laser) over 2 weeks, irradiated to the buccal and palatal sides.
study_duration: 2 weeks (with follow-up measurements up to 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Acupuncture (LLLA) in alleviating acute postincisional pain and compare its efficacy to electroacupuncture (EA).
results_summary: All three LLLA treatments reduced mechanical pain (tactile allodynia) in the affected paw, with the 30-minute red laser treatment also improving pain in the contralateral paw and showing efficacy similar to EA. However, LLLA had minimal effect on heat hyperalgesia, and the 30-minute red laser group reversed increases in spinal cord markers linked to pain sensitization.
population_specificity: Male adult rats with induced plantar incision pain.
effective_dosage: GaAlAs laser irradiation (two red laser groups: 30- or 15-minute durations; one near-infrared laser group: 30-minute duration).
study_duration: 5 days (immediately post-operation and the following 4 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of PBMT (low-level laser therapy) on postexercise skeletal muscle recovery and identify the optimal output power for enhancing recovery.
results_summary: PBMT with 100 mW and 200 mW power outputs improved maximum isometric voluntary contraction (MIVC), reduced delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS), and lowered biochemical markers of muscle damage, inflammation, and oxidative stress, with 100 mW showing the best results. Higher power outputs (400 mW) did not yield better outcomes.
population_specificity: 28 high-level soccer players
effective_dosage: 10 J per site, with output powers of 100, 200, or 400 mW per diode (total 500, 1000, or 2000 mW for five diodes)
study_duration: Single application before exercise, with follow-up assessments up to 96 hours post-exercise

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on bone healing following rapid maxillary expansion (RME).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT had stimulatory effects on bone regeneration after RME in both human and animal studies, though discrepancies in intervention protocols existed. Long-term clinical trials are needed to establish reliable protocols.
population_specificity: Human clinical trial participants undergoing RME and animal models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-, medium-, and long-term effects of PBMT on pain intensity and disability in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain.
results_summary: The study is a randomized placebo-controlled trial assessing PBMT's effects, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome results, only the methodology and planned measurements.
population_specificity: 148 patients with chronic non-specific low back pain.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions (3 times per week for 4 weeks).
study_duration: 4 weeks of treatment, with follow-ups at 3, 6, and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low-level laser irradiation on the proliferation of human dental pulp mesenchymal stem cells through a literature review.
results_summary: The review suggests that low-level laser therapy (LLLT) may be a useful tool for advancing cell therapy and tissue engineering, particularly with stem cells, and shows promising results in regenerating dental tissues.
population_specificity: Human dental pulp mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy in reducing postoperative pain and improving neurosensory recovery after orthognathic surgery.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy was effective in reducing postoperative pain at 24 and 72 hours and improving neurosensory recovery at 60 days and six months post-surgery, with statistically significant results. However, the small number and heterogeneity of studies prevented a meta-analysis or definitive recommendation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthognathic surgery.
study_duration: Varied across studies (24 hours, 72 hours, 60 days, six months post-surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) as an oral care tool for managing side effects of head and neck radiotherapy (HNRT).
results_summary: The study found that while mucositis severity was similar between groups, the LLLT group had fewer interruptions in oncologic therapy due to mucositis, reduced need for nasogastric tube nutrition, and less intense trismus compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 216 patients undergoing head and neck radiotherapy (HNRT).
effective_dosage: Applied three times weekly (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of HNRT (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on reducing complications (pain, trismus, swelling) after the surgical removal of impacted mandibular third molars.
results_summary: The study found low to moderate certainty evidence that LLLT provides negligible benefits in reducing pain, trismus, and swelling post-surgery, with no significant adverse effects reported. The authors concluded that evidence does not support LLLT's clinical use for this purpose.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgical extraction of impacted mandibular third molars.
study_duration: Outcomes measured at 2 and 7 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on orthodontically induced inflammatory root resorption (OIIRR) and compare pulsed versus continuous LLLT delivery.
results_summary: LLLT resulted in 23% less root resorption compared to placebo, with pulsed delivery showing a non-significant 5% advantage over continuous delivery. No harm was observed.
population_specificity: Twenty adolescent patients requiring bilateral maxillary first premolar orthodontic extractions.
effective_dosage: AlGaAs diode laser of 808 nm wavelength, 0.18 W power, 1.6 J per point, duration of 9s (continuous) or 4.5s (pulsed), administered on days 0, 1, 2, 3, 7, 14, and 21.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current management guidelines for mucositis in HSCT patients, including the role of Low-Level Laser Therapy (photobiomodulation) in preventing oral mucositis.
results_summary: The study highlights that Low-Level Laser Therapy is one of the few recommended interventions for oral mucositis in HSCT patients, as per MASCC/ISOO guidelines, though overall research remains limited and lacks robust evidence.
population_specificity: Adult and pediatric patients receiving hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different power levels of high-intensity laser therapy (HILT) in treating fibromyalgia symptoms in a patient resistant to conventional treatments.
results_summary: The study found that low-power (1 W) HILT provided minimal relief, while intermediate (42 W) and high-power (75 W) HILT significantly reduced pain, improved sleep quality, and increased physical activity for 4-10 days post-treatment. However, earlier studies on low-level laser therapy (LLLT) showed mixed results, with one sham-controlled study finding no significant benefit over sham treatment.
population_specificity: A woman with long-standing fibromyalgia syndrome resistant to standard pharmacotherapy and interdisciplinary pain management.
effective_dosage: 1 W, 42 W, and 75 W HILT administered at the paraspinous region and tender points in the shoulder and hip regions.
study_duration: Series of treatments (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of physical therapy and electrophysical modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: Moderate evidence was found for LLLT in the short term for CTS, but no long-term effects were studied. The study noted heterogeneity in treatment parameters, preventing identification of optimal dosages.
population_specificity: Patients with carpal tunnel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for provoked vestibulodynia (PVD) in a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blinded trial.
results_summary: LLLT showed improvement in clinical pain reports (78% vs. 44% in placebo), but this effect was not observed in other outcome measures. At 1-year follow-up, 57% of patients reported lasting improvement, and no side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with provoked vestibulodynia (PVD), a sexual pain disorder characterized by vulvar vestibule pain upon contact or pressure.
effective_dosage: Twice weekly for 6 weeks (total of 12 sessions).
study_duration: 6 weeks of intervention, with a 1-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy could inhibit or decrease the rate of orthodontic tooth movement in humans.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in the inhibition of orthodontic tooth movement when using an 860 nm continuous wave GaAlA low-level laser compared to placebo after 90 days of observation.
population_specificity: Humans undergoing orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on postoperative pain following root canal retreatment (RCR) of mandibular molars.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced postoperative pain in the first 4 days compared to placebo, with fewer patients requiring analgesics. No significant differences were observed after 5 and 7 days, and no pain was reported during LLLT application.
population_specificity: Patients requiring RCR on mandibular molars with periapical lesions (Periapical Index scores 2 or 3) and baseline pain VAS <50.
study_duration: Intervention effects were assessed over 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in managing temporomandibular joint (TMJ) pain compared to a placebo in a randomized, double-blind study.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT reduced TMJ pain and improved mouth opening and clicking in both active and placebo groups, but there was no significant difference between the groups, suggesting LLLT was not more effective than placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with TMJ pain (n=40, split into two groups of 20 each).
effective_dosage: 2-3 treatments per week for 8 sessions, using a diode laser (gallium aluminum arsenide, 810 nm, 0.1 W).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in muscle activity, bite force, and salivary cortisol in children with bruxism after applying low-level laser therapy to acupoints.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a comparison of low-level laser therapy, occlusal splints, placebo laser, and a control group, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children with bruxism.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at one and six months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Multiwave Locked System (MLS) laser therapy versus 830 nm low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating chronic neck pain when combined with exercises.
results_summary: Both MLS laser therapy and LLLT combined with exercises significantly reduced pain and improved neck function, but MLS showed greater reductions in pain (Δ VAS 6.68) and disability (Δ NDI 39.84) compared to LLLT and placebo after 6 weeks. The study concluded that MLS laser therapy plus exercises was more effective than LLLT plus exercises or exercises alone for chronic neck pain.
population_specificity: 75 patients with chronic neck pain (mean age 46.28 ± 5.89, mean illness duration 5.98 ± 1.44 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of LLLT and LIPUS, alone or combined with bone grafts or other factors, on fracture healing in animal models and patients.
results_summary: The study found that both LIPUS and LLLT may benefit fracture healing, with LIPUS being more effective. LIPUS could significantly reduce nonunion rates, but further high-quality clinical trials are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Animal models and patients with fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) versus corticosteroid therapy in treating oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: The study found weak scientific evidence to conclude whether LLLT is more effective than corticosteroids for OLP, with high risk of bias in most included studies. Further randomized clinical trials are recommended.
population_specificity: Humans diagnosed clinically and/or histologically with oral lichen planus (OLP).
effective_dosage: Laser wavelengths (630-970 nm), power (10-3000 mW), spot size (0.2-1.0 cm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) combined with strengthening exercises in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that improvements in pain and osteoarthritis severity after LLLT plus exercise were maintained for six months, with significantly lower paracetamol consumption in the LLLT group compared to placebo. No significant differences were observed in other outcomes between groups at follow-up.
population_specificity: 40 participants aged 50-75 years with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2-4).
effective_dosage: 10 LLLT treatments (904 nm, 3 Joules/point) over three weeks.
study_duration: Three weeks of LLLT followed by eight weeks of supervised exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between photobiomodulation (PBM) and bone regeneration, focusing on the impact of dose and output power.
results_summary: The study found a positive effect of low-level laser energy on bone regeneration when specific dose-power relationships were used, stimulating cellular metabolism and protein synthesis. However, results were inconsistent across studies, with some reporting no significant effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro, in vivo, and clinical studies reviewed).
effective_dosage: High dose with low power or low dose with high power (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) applied during percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) could influence restenosis by affecting nitric oxide (NO) and endothelin-1 concentrations.
results_summary: LLLT led to statistically higher nitrite/nitrate concentrations compared to the control group, except pre-PCI, and initially higher endothelin-1 levels that decreased over time. The restenosis rate was lower in the laser group (15.0%) than the control group (32.4%), though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 52 subjects undergoing PCI (laser group) and 49 controls (PCI only).
effective_dosage: 808 nm intravascular LLLT at 9 J/cm² in the lesion part.
study_duration: Single application during PCI, with follow-up at 6 h, 12 h, 1 month, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on chronic venous leg ulcers (VLUs), specifically assessing wound closure, ulcer size, and pain reduction.
results_summary: The study compared LLLT (635 nm) to placebo over 12 weeks, measuring outcomes like complete wound closure, ulcer size reduction, and pain relief, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with a 6-week history of chronic venous leg ulcers (VLUs) ranging in size from 5 to 20 cm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) improves survival outcomes (overall, disease-free, and progression-free survival) in head and neck cancer patients undergoing chemoradiotherapy.
results_summary: Patients receiving LLLT showed significantly better complete response rates (89.1% vs. 67.4%) and progression-free survival (61.7% vs. 40.4%) compared to the placebo group, with a trend toward improved overall survival (57.4% vs. 40.4%).
population_specificity: 94 patients diagnosed with oropharynx, nasopharynx, and hypopharynx cancer undergoing chemoradiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) with therapeutic ultrasound and extracorporeal shock wave therapy in treating chronic plantar fasciitis using MRI.
results_summary: The study compared LLLT to other therapies but did not provide specific outcome details in the abstract. It was a randomized, prospective clinical study involving 60 patients.
population_specificity: 60 patients diagnosed with chronic plantar fasciitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) could improve bone quality by stimulating osteoporotic mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) to enhance osteogenic differentiation and bone structure.
results_summary: LLLT stimulated growth, proliferation, and differentiation of MSCs in vitro and in vivo, suggesting potential for improving bone structure in osteoporotic patients. However, further research is needed to validate effectiveness and clinical feasibility.
population_specificity: Osteoporotic animal models and in vitro cultured osteoporotic bone marrow MSCs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for pain control during fixed orthodontic appliance therapy compared to ibuprofen.
results_summary: LLLT reduced pain intensity during fixed orthodontic therapy, with statistically significant effects observed at 2 hours and 3 to 7 days postoperatively. However, the evidence for LLLT was limited compared to ibuprofen, which showed significant pain reduction within the first day.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing fixed orthodontic appliance therapy (315 patients across six studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) for patients with carpal tunnel syndrome, comparing it to placebo treatment and assessing its effects over time.
results_summary: Strong evidence supports LLLT's effectiveness compared to placebo in the very short term (0 to ≤5 weeks), but positive effects on pain, function, or recovery diminished after 5 weeks, with moderate and conflicting evidence at 7- and 12-week follow-ups.
population_specificity: Patients with carpal tunnel syndrome.
study_duration: Effects were assessed at 0 to ≤5 weeks (very short term), 7 weeks (midterm), and 12 weeks (long term).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) with other non-surgical treatments for temporomandibular disorders (TMD) in improving clinical symptoms and joint effusion.
results_summary: LLLT was as effective as splint therapy, arthrocentesis, and medical therapy in increasing mouth opening and reducing pain scores at 1, 3, and 6 months post-treatment, with no statistically significant differences between the groups. Joint effusion, though associated with pain, did not decrease after treatment.
population_specificity: 40 patients with unilateral TMD classified under group II of the Research Diagnostic Criteria for Temporomandibular Disorders (RDC/TMD).
study_duration: Follow-up at 1, 3, and 6 months post-treatment (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in managing mild-to-moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) by comparing its effects with placebo on functional and electromyographic outcomes.
results_summary: LLLT showed no significant improvement over placebo in pain reduction, functional status, or motor electrodiagnostic evaluations but was superior in improving grip strength and inferior in sensory nerve action potential. The study concluded that further high-quality trials are needed to establish LLLT's efficacy for CTS.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (473 patients/631 wrists).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if laser photobiomodulation (PBM) could enhance wound healing and reduce postoperative pain following free gingival graft (FGG) procedures.
results_summary: PBM accelerated epithelialization at the donor site but did not reduce postoperative pain. The test group showed better healing at specific time points (days 1 and 14) but no significant difference in pain scores except for greater pain in the first 3 hours post-procedure.
population_specificity: Twelve patients undergoing split-mouth FGG procedures.
effective_dosage: Diode laser (660nm, 200mW, continuous mode, 32s irradiation, energy density: 4J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-level laser therapy and light-emitting diode could improve neurosensory recovery of the inferior alveolar nerve after sagittal split osteotomy.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy significantly improved visual analog scale (VAS) scores and brush stroke test results at various follow-up intervals, with no effect on pinprick or contact detection tests. Improvements were observed as early as 1 week and persisted up to 6 months.
population_specificity: 20 subjects with inferior alveolar nerve injury following sagittal split osteotomy of the mandible.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments were conducted on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 60, and 180 post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in treating symptomatic oral lichen planus (OLP) and determine its potential as an alternative to corticosteroids.
results_summary: All included studies found LLLT effective in managing OLP without reported adverse effects, supporting its use as an alternative to corticosteroids, though methodological variations highlight the need for further large-scale trials.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic oral lichen planus (OLP).
effective_dosage: Laser wavelengths (630-980 nm), power output (20-300 mW), and irradiation duration (10 s-15 min).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LASER) and Interferential current in reducing post-stroke shoulder pain and improving patient satisfaction, disability, and functional levels.
results_summary: LASER therapy significantly improved pain and satisfaction levels (p<0.001) but did not significantly enhance functional levels (p>0.05). It was found more effective than Interferential current for pain reduction and satisfaction in stroke patients with shoulder pain.
population_specificity: 38 diagnosed post-stroke patients with shoulder pain (20 in LASER group, 18 in Interferential current group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) on masseter muscle thickness, mouth opening amplitude, and oral health-related quality of life in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study compared outcomes between children with CP (with and without oral complaints) and a control group without CP, using PBMT on masseter muscles. Results suggested potential benefits, but specific efficacy details are not fully described in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (with and without oral complaints) and a control group without CP.
effective_dosage: Infrared low-level Ga-Al-As laser (λ = 808 ± 3 nm, 120 mW) at 3 J/cm² (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-level laser therapy (LLLT) is effective in treating neurosensory impairment following bilateral sagittal split osteotomy (BSSO).
results_summary: LLLT showed no significant difference compared to the control side initially, but by postoperative days 45 and 60, the laser-treated side demonstrated significantly improved two-point discrimination. The study concluded that LLLT accelerates recovery of sensory disturbances after BSSO.
population_specificity: Patients requiring bilateral sagittal split osteotomy (BSSO).
effective_dosage: 660-nm laser, 200 mW, 10 seconds, 2 J, 1.5 J/cm² per application.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the penetration time profiles of two different lasers (810 nm and 904 nm) used in Low-Level Laser Therapy in relaxed and stretched human Achilles tendons.
results_summary: The 904 nm laser showed significantly higher and increasing penetration ability over time compared to the 810 nm laser, which had constant penetration. Stretching the Achilles tendon caused higher energy attenuation for both lasers.
population_specificity: 17 healthy volunteers (34 Achilles tendons).
effective_dosage: 810 nm, 200 mW continuous laser; 904 nm, 60 mW super-pulsed laser.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of a single application of low-level laser therapy (4-Joule or 16-Joule energy) on pain reduction following elastomeric separators placement in orthodontic patients.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant pain reduction from low-level laser therapy at either 4-Joule or 16-Joule energy levels compared to placebo. No harms were reported.
population_specificity: 26 patients (25 analyzed) requiring orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances.
study_duration: Immediate post-application assessment at 1, 6, 12, 24, 48, and 72 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal dosage of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for improving cyclists' performance in time-to-exhaustion tests and its effects on muscle fatigue mechanisms.
results_summary: LLLT increased time to exhaustion in cyclists, with the 135 J dosage showing the best performance improvement (~22 seconds) and increased high-frequency EMG content. The 270 J and 405 J dosages also improved performance (~13 seconds each) but did not significantly affect muscle activation compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Twenty male competitive cyclists.
effective_dosage: 135 J, 270 J, and 405 J per thigh, applied bilaterally before each test.
study_duration: 5 days (1 incremental test day followed by 4 time-to-exhaustion test days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of diode lasers in managing orofacial pain compared to traditional procedures.
results_summary: The study found that Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) is more effective than traditional methods for managing orofacial pain related to soft and hard tissue conditions, such as premalignant lesions, gingival conditions, and dental extractions. However, the optimal wavelength for predictable pain reduction remains undetermined, and further randomized controlled trials are recommended.
population_specificity: Patients with orofacial pain associated with soft and hard tissue conditions (e.g., premalignant lesions, gingival conditions, dental extractions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining low-level laser therapy with conventional facial exercises improves functional outcomes in patients with facial paralysis during early recovery.
results_summary: The study compared outcomes between patients receiving low-level laser therapy plus facial exercises and those receiving facial exercises alone, suggesting potential benefits of the combined approach, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 46 patients (mean age 41 ± 9.7 years; 40 women, 6 men) with facial paralysis.
effective_dosage: 830 nm wavelength, 100 mW output power, 1 KHz frequency, mean energy density of 10 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence supporting Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as a method to accelerate orthodontic tooth movement.
results_summary: The study found some evidence suggesting LLLT is associated with accelerated orthodontic tooth movement, but the quality of current evidence is low to moderate, necessitating further research before routine recommendation.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the phototherapeutic effects of high-powered continuous, low-powered continuous, and low-powered pulsed laser/light therapies on muscle performance and recovery after eccentric exercise.
results_summary: Low-powered pulsed laser/light therapy maintained maximum voluntary contraction, reduced delayed-onset muscle soreness, and decreased creatine kinase activity compared to placebo and other laser/light groups. High-powered continuous laser/light showed no positive effects and even increased creatine kinase activity compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Forty healthy untrained male participants.
effective_dosage: A single dose of 180 J applied to the quadriceps.
study_duration: Single intervention with follow-up measurements up to 96 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the physiologic effects and clinical efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) at 650 nm for promoting hair regrowth in females with androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT using the HANDI-DOME LASER device every other day for 17 weeks resulted in a 51% increase in hair counts compared to sham-treated controls, demonstrating significant efficacy for treating androgenetic alopecia. The treatment was also deemed safe for the studied population.
population_specificity: Healthy females aged 18-60 with Fitzpatrick skin Types I-IV and Ludwig-Savin Baldness Scale I-2 to II-2 patterns.
effective_dosage: 650 nm laser light, administered every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) using Nd:YAG (1064 nm) and diode (810 nm) lasers in treating subjective tinnitus related to temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: Both Nd:YAG and 810 nm diode laser treatments showed statistically significant reductions in tinnitus severity (p=0.001 and p=0.005, respectively), while the placebo group showed no significant difference (p=0.065). The effects persisted one month post-treatment.
population_specificity: 46 patients with bilateral subjective tinnitus and TMDs.
effective_dosage: LLLT applied once per day for 10 days (specific energy settings not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transcutaneous or intraoral low-level laser therapy (LLLT) reduces postoperative pain and aids healing after mandibular third molar extraction.
results_summary: Intraoral LLLT significantly reduced postoperative pain compared to transcutaneous LLLT and placebo, but no differences in socket healing were observed by the seventh day. The study concluded that intraoral LLLT is more effective for pain reduction than extraoral application.
population_specificity: 60 patients with full bony impacted mandibular third molars bilaterally.
effective_dosage: Laser energy administered immediately before and after extraction using GaAlAs 830 nm diode lasers (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Single session (immediately before and after extraction), with follow-up for 1 week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) improves clinical outcomes and modulates inflammatory markers in smoking and non-smoking patients with chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: LLLT showed no significant differences in clinical parameters compared to sham treatment, but it modulated tPA and PAI-1 levels, particularly in smokers. Both LLLT and sham groups showed significant reductions in TGF-β1 levels.
population_specificity: 30 patients with chronic periodontitis (15 smokers, 15 non-smokers) and 30 healthy controls matched for age, sex, and smoking status.
effective_dosage: LLLT was applied on the same day as SRP and again on days 2 and 7 post-treatment.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments were conducted up to day 30.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain, hand function, and grip strength in adults with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) compared to placebo.
results_summary: The review found no strong evidence supporting the effects of LLLT on CTS, with heterogeneity in LLLT regimes preventing statistical pooling. Some studies using 780-860 nm lasers and energy dosages of 9-11 J/cm² showed potential benefits.
population_specificity: Adults with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in enhancing bone repair in the maxillofacial area and its secondary effects on healing, inflammation, and quality of life.
results_summary: Four of six studies showed improved bone formation with LLLT, while secondary outcomes indicated anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and healing accelerator effects with no reported adverse effects. However, results were mixed, with some studies showing benefits only at specific follow-up periods or no additional benefits.
population_specificity: 374 patients (mean age 28.5 years) with maxillofacial conditions such as tooth extraction, distraction osteogenesis, and periodontal defects.
effective_dosage: Wavelengths varied from 500 to 1000nm; GaAs and GaAlAs were commonly used devices (specific dosage parameters not detailed).
